messageBody:
Thanks for the responses. I am trying out JMock2 at the moment; I can
develop on Java5 even though the production code gets deployed to Java4.

I quite like the API, and apparently from Elliotte's recent reporting at
JavaOne, Builders are expected to become more prevalent!

http://www.cafeaulait.org/#May_9_2007_46487

JMock2 not quite as nice[1] as the previous framework that I used, since the
examples on the site seem to have omitted all the casts that are required.

context.checking(new Expectations() {{
one (subscriber).receive(message);
}});

But in practice with JMock2, it would seem to be:

context.checking(new Expectations() {{
((Subscriber) one (subscriber)).receive(message);
}});

Previously, I would have had something like:

subscriber.expects.receive(message).once();

Where subscriber isn't a plain Subscriber reference; it's a reference to a
SubscriberMock generated-class that implements Subscriber, along with some
additional functionality / fields.

But then you don't have to worry about generating the mock code when you use
JMock. YMMV, and that's a minor point.

I also like that JMock2 isn't invasive, in that we have a lot of JUnit3 test
cases and I don't need to alter the existing inheritance hierarchy. It'll do
for now until I start to feel some pain and then see whether any of the
other solutions available can address that particular pinch point for me.

Cheers,

James

[1] I'm using 'nice' in the Northern English sense of "I prefer bitter to
lager, but it's not worth worrying about".
